did.unittitle: League of Women Voters of Dearborn-Dearborn Heights records 1953-1978
did.abstract: Records of Dearborn and Dearborn Heights chapters of the League of Women Voters and (after April 1972) of the combined chapter; include minutes, newsletters, issue files, correspondence, files of study committees, and voter guides and other voter information.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The records were received from the League (donor no. 6889) on January 20, 1983.

accessrestrict.p: The record group is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, League of Women Voters of Dearborn-Dearborn Heights records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: The League of Women Voters is a nonpartisan, volunteer organization whose purpose is to promote political responsibility through the informed and active participation of citizens in government. Its major concern is voter education, and before most elections, it publishes a voters guide with information about the candidates and the various ballot proposals. The League also sponsors public forums, interviews candidates, and otherwise works to get out the vote. As a nonpartisan group, the League does not take a position on political parties or candidates, only on issues, and only after it has made a thorough study of the subject and its membership has reached a consensus.

The development of the Dearborn-Dearborn Heights League of Women is somewhat more complicated than other local leagues. It began first as a unit discussion group of the Detroit LWV. Here the group studied a wide range of Detroit, state, and national issues, but very little about local Dearborn affairs. As a result, the leadership of this group began working to have their own league chapter. In March 1951, a provisional league was formed; in December 1951, that provisional league was formally recognized as the League of Women Voters of Dearborn.

With the growth and development of this area of the state in the 1950's and 1960's, some felt there might be a need for a separate league for Dearborn Heights. A provisional league was recognized in 1967, but after five years, its members voted to disband. At the same time as that dissolution, April 20, 1972, the members of the Dearborn LWV voted to reorganize, enlarging the basis of their organization, and changing its name to the League of Women Voters of Dearborn-Dearborn Heights.

scopecontent.p: The records of the League of Women Voters of Dearborn-Dearborn Heights have been arranged into four series: Dearborn league files, Dearborn Heights league files, State Programs, National Programs, and Photographs.

scopecontent.p: The Dearborn league files covers the years 1953 to 1978, with most of the papers falling in the period of 1961-1975. Included are minutes of annual meetings and board meetings, correspondence, newsletters, local program files, study committee files, and Voter Service guides and working files. Studies undertaken by the league ranged over a number of topics, including the Dearborn school system, environmental quality, the welfare system, and the relationship between the Michigan courts and the juveniles and children brought before them. The records created after April 20, 1972 are of the merged League of Women Voters of Dearborn-Dearborn Heights.

scopecontent.p: The Dearborn Heights files covers the years 1965 to 1972, the period before the reorganization of the Dearborn LWV into the LWV of Dearborn-Dearborn Heights. Material about Dearborn Heights after 1972 will be found in the Dearborn series. The Dearborn Heights files also includes minutes of board meetings, newsletters, and Voter Service material. Some of the subject files in this series concerned the Crestwood School Board recall and a study of police-community relations.

did.unittitle: Dearborn Heights, City With a Future 1967

scopecontent.p: Of special interest in the State Programs series is the Call to Action. Once the League has taken a position on a bill before the state legislature, and that bill is at a "critical point" in the legislature process, the League will issue a Call to Action asking the local leagues and other interested parties to make known to the appropriate legislators the League's position. This step is taken only with bills considered "vital" by the League.

did.unittitle: Proposal C (Re Aid to Non-Public Schools) 1970

scopecontent.p: The National Programs series includes several files relating to the League's position on national issues. There is also a folder of Time for Action which is similar to the Call for Action on the state level, except that the issues are national in scope.

did.unittitle: Photos of proclamation ceremonies with Mayor Orville Hubbard participating
